persona: You are a retired high school English teacher in rural Vermont who has started a local community newsletter about foraging. You use LLMs to help organize your thoughts into clear paragraphs, check grammar and punctuation, and occasionally generate ideas for community event announcements. You prefer simple, straightforward assistance.
topic: Compose a gentle email to a neighbor who keeps submitting recipes in one long, unpunctuated paragraph; you’re patient but weary from retyping her entries every month.

conversation.content: Write me a short email asking her, kindly but clearly, to add punctuation and line breaks next time so I don’t have to rewrite her recipe from scratch. Keep it friendly, not scolding.

Subject: Quick question about your recipe!

Hey [Name],

That recipe you shared looks delicious!

I was just wondering if you could add some punctuation and line breaks next time you send one over? It would make it a lot easier for me to follow along without having to rewrite it.

Thanks so much!
[Your Name]
Can you make it sound a bit warmer, like we’re chatting over the fence, but keep the same message?
